utterances: Dolores Hernandez Jimenez(ph) walks out of the relocation institute into the bitter cold.
She said she thought she'd be relocated within a month.
(Speaking in foreign language)
That's--you're absolutely right.
You had three very different personalities and, equally important, three very different sets of skills that started Intel.
So the way that someone pointed out to me, which I thought was beautifully is that Noyce was sort of the long-range vision guy and your outside guy.
He would sort of receive signals from the outside and say, `Someday, we're going to be able to use semiconductors to do some fantastic thing.
And then Gordon Moore would be the person to say, `Hmm, well to do that we're going to need to break through this technical barrier, and think about these big ideas.
And then Andy Grove would be the guy down in the trenches, saying, `Well, that means we have to hire however many new engineers and build X amount of new fab space.
So they did all three mesh together and complement each other very well.
And at Fairchild, too, those eight guys who started Fairchild had been chosen by Shockley specifically because their knowledge complemented each other so well.
They made a fantastic team and spent a lot of time together.

At some point in the book, I describe how they would stand in a circle, shoulder to shoulder, just talking, lighting each other's cigarettes, holding two or three conversations simultaneously, and just the energy and excitement that they brought to this whole idea was fascinating and a very important part of their success early on.
Thanks for calling.
Thanks.
I look forward to reading the book.
Thank you.
1 (800) 989-8255 is our number.
Joe in New Jersey--Hi, Joe.
Hi.
Thanks for--I'm so glad you took my call.
Hi, Leslie.

I am more of a MTV generation than a generation of the past of Bob Noyce and that--and what not--I just was more asking about the days of today and Apple Computer's creation, like you said, with Steve Jobs, and the perspiration and--the inspiration and the perspiration.
Steve Wozeak being, perhaps, the perspiration of Apple Computer, and creating the first personal computer.
And I was wondering if you got to interview him or touch upon anything related to that relationship as others in the--in--before that in your book.
I talked to Steve Jobs.
I did not talk to Steve Wozeak.

Well, I want to say one thing, as a friend of Steve's, and someone who knows that relationship very well, I got to visit recently Steve Wozeak and about three weeks ago he had on his table, like you had mentioned finding in people's basements and garages, Steve Wozeak had on his table a little notebook with all his pencil scratchings and erasings of the creation of the first Apple Computer and the first code, the first--I think it was BASIC or DOS code.
I wouldn't even know it, being a non-techie.
And I couldn't even believe it.
And I'm, like, `Steve, this belongs in the Smithsonian.
And he's like `Oh...'
Or...
It was so easy to do to me back then.
I just spent...
Leslie wants it.
Yeah.

I was just gonna say, `Actually, we have at Stanford the Apple Computer collection and that would be a perfect thing to include, or anchor, that collection,' so, Steve Wozeak, if you're listening, give us a call.
Thanks for calling, Joe, and good luck.
1 (800) 989-8255 is our number.
What is the future of Silicon Valley?

Is it--has it seen its best days or the competition from overseas--you know, I was talking to the chairman of the board of Intel recently and he said, `You know, we don't have to hire another person in the United States.
We don't have to build another factory.
We are--most of our business now is from abroad.
You know?
Have we seen the best days of Silicon Valley?

Well, you know, the death knell of Silicon Valley has been sounded many times with the Japanese competition being sort of the most recent incarnation and one of the reasons that the subtitle of the book is ""The Invention of Silicon Valley"" is that this area and the people in this area have had the ability to reinvent themselves and their interests again and again.
And when Noyce died in 1990 who would have thought that you were gonna rejuvenate the entire area with this whole Internet and networking concept?
It just wasn't out there but it rose from the fertile soil that we've got here.
Well, Leslie, thank you very much for taking time to talk with us.

Leslie Berlin is the author of a new book, ""The Man Behind the Microchip: Robert Noyce and the Invention of Silicon Valley,"" a really interesting read if you would like to know about the man and the institution that was created.
She's also project historian for the Silicon Valley Archives.
(Credits)
If you missed any of the links we talked about, surf over to sciencefriday.com.
We're podcasting SCIENCE FRIDAY.
You can download this and back editions of SCIENCE FRIDAY to your iPod or listen to RealAudio or take it with you on your audible.com player.
I'm Ira Flatow in New York.
In Great Britain, campaigning is back on for Thursday's referendum on whether the U.K.
should remain in the European Union.
A pause was called after last week's shocking murder of Jo Cox.
She was a member of Parliament from the left-wing Labour Party who supported the U.K.
staying in the EU.
At her memorial service yesterday, her sister, Kim Leadbeater, had this to say.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We have to continue this strength and solidarity in the days, months and years to come as part of Jo's legacy and to focus on, as Jo would say, that which unites us, and not which divides us.
(Through interpreter) I think that's when she gave up on seeking help, thinking that if I couldn't make a difference, neither could she.
And for Jo Cox, that would have been staying in the EU.
Brexit - as in exiting the EU, as it's called there in Britain - is often presented as a right-wing initiative, but that's not true for our next guest.
Kate Hoey is a member of the Labour Party.
She's been in Parliament for 27 years, and she supports Brexit.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Now, it is so often identified with anti-immigrant, isolationist, right-wing folks in Great Britain.
What - but the view from the left - tell us how you see the EU harming the interest of British workers.
Yeah, well, the United Kingdom has been part of this common market which became the European Union for some 41 years.
The people of the country have never had the opportunity to say anything about the changes since 1975.
What Labour used to be was a very, very anti-EU party.
Then it became more interested in working with the European Union because they thought it was going to help improve workers' rights and be a social Europe.
Of course, that has all changed.
And now, on the left, we see - those of us within Labour and in the trade union movement - see the EU as a supporter of the multinationals, the global corporations.
It's a very neoliberal organization.
But crucially to the whole debate in the United Kingdom - that's in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and England - is the question of sovereignty and democracy.
At the moment, 27 other countries have a say in many, many of our laws.
So the British Parliament - over my years as an MP, I've seen power being taken away from our Parliament and going to Brussels.
And we want to get that back because that means that we can control our borders, which most democratic countries do, and we can trade with the rest of the world.
So we don't think it's isolationist.
We think we're the fifth-largest economy.

We're a quite big enough country to be independently running our own lives and working, cooperating, of course, with the rest of the world, including the United States of America, which is very important.
Well, let me get back to - you were talking about workers and what was good for workers.
I mean, those who are fighting to remain in the EU argue that Britain's economy could take a big hit.
And let me just give you one of the many examples.
They say billions of dollars in - or pounds in foreign investment could be lost from companies wanting to export to the EU free of tariffs.
I mean, that's just one small level line that people have.
But you've argued otherwise.
Yes.
I mean, we - we don't accept that.
I mean, many of these experts - the big institutions, the big banks, the big global corporations - it's in their interest for us to stay in the EU.
And for many of the leaders of other countries, it's in their interest for us to stay in.
What we're talking about is the interest of our country.

But also, many of these experts were the very same experts - the financial experts who told us that, if the United Kingdom didn't join the single currency, the euro, which we didn't, fortunately, you know, the country would be finished.
All these things would happen.
People - the city of London would be finished.
Trade would stop.
They - the experts are not necessarily always correct.
And I think we have very, very clear that, with being such a big country, you know, trading would continue.
The EU sells more to us than we sell to them.
The German car manufacturers are not going to stop selling us their cars.
And of course, America trades with the European Union without tariffs.
You know, this whole idea that you have to be within this single market for businesses to work with other business is - is not accurate.

And we are very confident that, given the opportunity to work again with those commonwealth countries - some of the emerging, big economic countries in Asia and in South America - that's where we would be able to forge ahead and also be able to act as a catalyst for what is a very dysfunctional organization - the EU - to get it changed completely.
Let me play you, just briefly here, a clip from Nigel Farage.
He's the leader of the U.K.
Independence Party, campaigning, like you, for Britain to leave the EU.
And here are his comments on the impact of the murder of your colleague, Jo Cox.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
There was a big momentum developing right across the country, a tragic death, a pause.
Very difficult to know or to see, in the next three or four days, where either of the campaigns go in terms of the public once again connecting with it.
Could this indeed stall the Brexit campaign - the leaving campaign?
No.
Everyone has said it is quite ridiculous to link the murder of my colleague, Jo Cox, with anything to do with the referendum.
I mean, we've had three others members of Parliament murdered by the IRA over - over years - some years ago.
This - this is about democracy.
I think the American people would not - they want to have a trading relationship with Mexico and Canada.
They would not accept that Mexico - a court in Mexico could overrule their court.
They wouldn't accept open borders.
We have to get back to being a self-run, democratic country trading with the world.
Kate Hoey is a member of Parliament from the Labour Party and an advocate of Britain leaving the EU.
Republicans see next year as the chance to get rid of financial regulations known as Dodd-Frank passed during the Obama years.
Now, one blueprint for unwinding those regulations is the Financial Choice Act.
It's a series of reforms that would quite simply put the market in charge.
The proposed legislation was spearheaded by Republican Jeb Hensarling.
He's head of the House Financial Services Committee.
Earlier today, we spoke about his plan to do that.
And in that conversation, he made the argument that Dodd-Frank was affecting economic growth.
After Dodd-Frank, the big banks were bigger.
The small banks are fewer.
We're losing a community financial institution a day in America.
Do you - by that, do you mean community banks?
Community banks and credit unions - we're losing one a day.
But when the FDIC sort of studied that, didn't they find that, say, banks are often acquired by other community banks, right?

Well, they're usually acquired by larger banks because they cannot handle the weight, the load, the complexity and the expense of the Dodd-Frank regulatory onslaught in our community financial institutions, had little or nothing to do with the financial crisis.
What we're trying to do, again, is to foster economic growth and to minimize financial panics.
And the way we do that is to ensure that banks keep more loss-absorbing capital.
Consumers don't really understand compound interest.
And it's the effect of these small interest rate differences applied to a large sum of money - which a mortgage is - and then compounded over time.
It all started with a morning walk.
Clark County Commissioner Chris Giunchigliani took two and a half years ago.
She had on her sweats, her weights and her Walkman, which she uses to listen to, what else, NPR.
And she heard this report about green building.
And so I was like, oh, that's kind of an interesting concept.
Maybe it'd cost you more on the front end, but down the road, what you'll save in energy cost will be well worth it.
